text.p: Barclays Plc Plc on Monday urged its staff to vote against strike action in a ballot called by banking unions UNiFI and BIFU.
The bank accused the unions of ignoring the views of the "silent majority" and said it estimated that only one in six members of Barclays staff voted in favour of holding the strike ballot.

"Such a low turnout does not suggest that union members have any enthusiasm for industrial action," a Barclays spokesman said in a statement. "The silent majority of members clearly tore their ballot papers up."
The spokesman warned that staff who take industrial action will be in breach of their contracts.
Barclays said union claims it is instigating a pay and pensions freeze were "simply untrue".
"All staff have the potential to increase their earnings in the future through salary increases and/or performance related bonuses," the Barclays spokesman added.

The ballot, being conducted by unions UNiFI and BIFU, asks members if they are prepared to take industrial action including two- or three-day strikes and a ban on overtime, BIFU said in a statement earlier.
Balloting is due to finish on July 24.

The unions, which together represent more than three quarters of all Barclays staff, opposed what they called Barclays' plan to impose a new pay and grading structure based on performance which will result in a pay and pensions freeze for over half of staff.
The motive behind the company's plan is to cut staff costs and to cap staff's potential earnings, the unions said.
"To cap pay at a time when Barclays are making 2.35 billion stg profit is immoral," Jim Lowe, assistant secretary at BIFU, said.

Barclays denied its plan will produce a pay freeze but has conceded that staff whose pay is at the top of a particular salary band would not get a pay rise regardless of whether they exceeded their agreed performance plan.
But the Bank said over time, salary bands will move, allowing staff headroom to receive a performance-related increase.
